CASE 83:
DISCHARGE AGAINST MEDICAL ADVICE
Nora, a frail 82 year old lady with advanced lung cancer, is brought to A&E late at night by
ambulance. Her husband, her main carer, was admitted yesterday with pneumonia. He men-
tioned to staff that his wife was at home alone and was concerned she might not be managing
without him.
After she failed to answer the staff’s phone calls, an ambulance was dispatched, and she was
found in her chair, dehydrated and unable to mobilise. Since her husband’s admission she
had been too weak and breathless to get up, and had been unable to get herself anything to
eat or drink.
Fortunately her test results are normal and the A&E doctor suggests she stays overnight
so a carer can be arranged the following morning. The doctor explains to Nora they are
concerned that if she goes home she may become dehydrated or have a fall. Nora is adamant
she wants to go home, stating that she is fine, would rather sleep in her own bed, and will take
a sandwich from A&E for supper. She starts getting up and making her way towards the door.
She has no history of mental health problems.
Questions
• How should doctors approach patients who make decisions they consider unwise?
• What issues arise from the complex interplay between health and social care,
particularly during out of hours?

data.vignette: You are the emergency department physician overnight. An 82-year-old woman with advanced lung cancer is brought in after her husband and sole caregiver was hospitalized the day before. At home she had been too weak and short of breath to get up for food or fluids, and was found dehydrated and unable to transfer safely. In the ED she improves with fluids; basic labs and imaging do not show a new acute problem. She is alert, converses clearly, and repeatedly says she understands the staff’s concerns but insists on going home now because she wants to sleep in her own bed and does not want to stay in the hospital. Overnight social services cannot arrange reliable in-home support until morning, and staff worry she will fall or be unable to access food and water if discharged. The question is whether to let her leave now or keep her in the hospital until supports are in place.
data.choice_1: Discharge her tonight after confirming decision-making capacity, documenting the discussion, offering practical harm-reduction steps (e.g., food/drink to take, phone check-ins, return precautions), and honoring her stated wish to go home despite the foreseeable risks.
data.choice_2: Keep her in the hospital overnight despite her stated wish to leave, using the least restrictive measures available (continued observation, senior review, and involvement of on-call safeguarding/ethics as needed) so that safe support can be arranged in the morning and immediate preventable harm is less likely.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 an implementable, legally/clinically grounded order rather than a vague intent to 'keep her.' Specify the mechanism (e.g., place her in ED observation as a voluntary patient; OR, if you intend involuntary retention, state the jurisdiction-appropriate basis such as documented lack of decision-making capacity for discharge, acute delirium, or a formal 'medical incapacity hold' for grave disability) and what specific steps are authorized (e.g., refuse AMA discharge, security, restraints only if actively unsafe).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the missing facts needed to justify either allowing AMA discharge or temporarily retaining her: (1) a brief functional baseline and current mobility (can she ambulate/toilet? oxygen requirement?), (2) whether she has home oxygen/meds/food available tonight, (3) cognitive screen elements relevant to capacity for discharge planning (understands situation/risks/alternatives, can communicate a consistent choice), and (4) whether she meets criteria for hospice/palliative services already involved. Remove or tighten nonstandard/unclear phrases like 'on-call safeguarding' unless your setting actually has that service.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the real-world constraints and authority: in most EDs you cannot detain an alert, capacitated adult solely because discharge is unsafe. If you want Choice 2 to be plausible, add a clinically realistic trigger that makes temporary retention defensible (e.g., fluctuating mentation from dehydration, hypoxia requiring supplemental oxygen, inability to articulate a plan for obtaining food/water constituting grave disability, or concern for elder neglect with mandated protective custody). Otherwise revise Choice 2 to 'strongly recommend staying; offer observation admission; if she refuses, discharge AMA with mitigation.'

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 is ethically and legally hard to defend if she truly has intact decision-making capacity and no acute medical indication for admission; it becomes an obviously wrong/impermissible option rather than a reasonable alternative. To restore non-triviality, either (a) introduce a credible reason capacity is impaired/unstable (delirium risk, hypoxia, opioid toxicity), or (b) reframe Choice 2 as a voluntary short-stay/observation admission after persuasive counseling (not coercion), with the moral cost being potential unwanted hospitalization vs risk at home.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Revise the vignette so that both options are ethically/clinically defensible. As written, she is described as alert, understanding, and having decision-making capacity; in that setting, forcibly keeping her is typically not ethically defensible and collapses the dilemma into a near-rule ('respect a capacitated refusal'). To restore equipoise, add a concrete, serious reason to doubt capacity or voluntariness that could reasonably justify a short, least-restrictive hold (e.g., fluctuating attention after dehydration/opioids/hypoxia; inconsistent ability to paraphrase risks; intermittent somnolence; inability to sustain a coherent choice over time; evidence of delirium). Alternatively, change Choice 2 from 'keep her despite her stated wish' to 'time-limited observation to reassess capacity and ensure she can articulate a stable, informed refusal once medically optimized,' explicitly acknowledging that if capacity is confirmed she will be allowed to leave. Ensure Choice 1 also has genuine moral cost by specifying foreseeable severe harm (e.g., likely inability to access water/meds overnight, high fall risk without ability to call for help) without making it sound like medical negligence.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften framing that implies the patient is unsafe or irrational. For example, change “staff worry she will fall or be unable to access food and water” to “the team is concerned about her ability to meet basic needs overnight without assistance.” Avoid “keep her…despite her stated wish” language; rephrase both options in parallel, neutral terms (e.g., “discharge with…,” “continue ED/hospital observation until…”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to one paragraph and remove redundant statements. Combine capacity description and preference: e.g., “She is alert, oriented, and communicates a consistent wish to return home tonight.” Clarify whether she is requesting AMA discharge vs standard discharge. Specify the legal/clinical posture: is she on hospice, and what is her baseline functional status? Keep only details that affect the decision (caregiver unavailable, lack of overnight supports, capacity, immediate risks).

data.vignette: You are the ED attending caring for an 82-year-old woman with severe COPD and heart failure who came in for worsening shortness of breath and poor oral intake. After nebulizers and IV fluids she is less dyspneic but still needs low-flow supplemental oxygen; at baseline she uses home oxygen, ambulates short distances with a walker, and usually manages toileting and meals independently. Tonight she is intermittently drowsy and distractible, at times unable to repeat back the plan or explain how she will get oxygen, food, and her medications if she leaves; at other moments she is oriented and firmly states she wants to go home now and declines admission. She lives alone, her daughter who usually helps is out of town, and the patient reports her home oxygen concentrator is “not working” and she has no one who can check on her overnight. Palliative care has been discussed in the past but she is not enrolled in hospice. You must decide whether to allow her to leave now or to keep her in a least-restrictive, time-limited setting to clarify capacity and arrange safe discharge options.
data.choice_1: Honor her stated wish to leave tonight and discharge (including AMA documentation if she refuses recommended observation), with maximal feasible harm-reduction planning and follow-up.
data.choice_2: Place her in time-limited ED observation under a medical incapacity/temporary hold to treat reversible contributors and reassess decision-making capacity and discharge safety; if capacity is confirmed, allow discharge, and use restraints/security only if she becomes imminently unsafe.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by: (1) specifying objective safety risks if discharged now (e.g., persistent hypoxia/hypercapnia risk, no functioning home oxygen, no caregiver, inability to obtain meds/food overnight); (2) explicitly describing fluctuating capacity with concrete examples and documenting a brief bedside capacity screen; (3) clarifying that the proposed hold is least-restrictive, time-limited, and aimed at treating reversible delirium/hypercapnia and arranging safe discharge, not overriding a competent refusal; (4) tightening choices so Choice 1 emphasizes respect for autonomy despite risk, and Choice 2 emphasizes temporary limitation of autonomy to prevent foreseeable serious harm and reassess capacity.

data.vignette:
A 68-year-old man with severe COPD (FEV1 28%) and chronic hypercapnia is admitted for an acute exacerbation with pneumonia. He required BiPAP overnight; this morning his ABG on 2 L nasal cannula is pH 7.31, PaCO2 68, PaO2 58. He is intermittently somnolent, then agitated, repeatedly removing his oxygen and IV. Nursing documents that he accurately states his name and location but cannot consistently explain why he is hospitalized or the risks of leaving; when asked to repeat the plan, he says, “They’re keeping me here to bill me,” and insists he can “walk home and be fine,” despite needing assistance to stand. On a brief bedside capacity screen, he can communicate a choice but cannot demonstrate understanding or appreciation of the consequences of leaving, and his reasoning is tangential.

He demands discharge “right now” to smoke and “sleep in my own bed.” His home oxygen concentrator is broken (confirmed by his daughter by phone), and his portable tank is empty. He has no caregiver at home tonight; his daughter is out of town until tomorrow afternoon. The pharmacy is closed, and he has not filled his antibiotics or steroids. Weather is below freezing, and he lacks transportation other than walking several blocks. The team believes his confusion is likely reversible from hypercapnia/hypoxia and infection, and that a short period of continued treatment and reassessment could restore capacity and allow a safe, voluntary discharge plan.

choice_1.choice: Honor his request to leave against medical advice after explaining the risks as best as possible, documenting the discussion, and arranging whatever limited supplies are immediately available (e.g., a small oxygen cylinder if one can be obtained), even though his capacity is fluctuating and the team believes discharge tonight carries a high risk of respiratory failure and death.

choice_2.choice: Implement a time-limited, least-restrictive medical hold because he currently lacks decision-making capacity due to likely reversible hypercapnic delirium, with the goal of preventing foreseeable serious harm and reassessing capacity after treatment (e.g., continue oxygen/BiPAP as tolerated, treat infection, repeat capacity assessment in 6–12 hours), while simultaneously working on safe discharge logistics (repair/replace home oxygen, secure medications, and confirm a caregiver/transport) and releasing him as soon as he demonstrates capacity or a safe plan is in place.
